text: 500ml bottle from the Beer Cabin in Plattsburgh, NY. Bottled in late March. Nice roasted malt aroma with hints of maple sweetness. Light coffee and toasted notes. Light grassy hops. Hazy ruddy amber colored body with a medium light tan head. Starts with a grassy and herbal bitter hop flavor. Fair caramel malts in the middle, but then more bitterness comes in the finish. Quite hoppy. Malts are readily present in the nose, but hops seem to dominate.

500 ml bottle. Clear deep amber color (almost brown actually). Rocky off white head with good retention and lacing. Aromas: resinous hops, dark malts, light roast. Retronasal its fruity hops, sourish, caramel. Flavor is moderate to full bitter with loght toast - hardly any sweetness. Medium bodied. Finishes slightly dry, reasonably bitter.

Picked this one up after really enjoying Maine Beer Co.s MO last week. This one is another example of this brewery getting away with deservedly charging 7-8 bucks for a 16.9 oz bottle. It is quite simply the best amber ale type thing ever; although classified as such, it seems in a class all itself. It has a robust rich piney divine smell to it and looks like a fuzzy red panda. It tastes like a resiny malty vision from on high blasting you with hoppy goodness and a brown backbone. Im granting this an elusive 4.4. Good for lazy Saturdays with too cold baths and disco jams.

A zesty caramel and spice aroma.. A cloudy brown body topped with a light tan head about an inch thick to start. Crisp roasted malt with a hint of caramel. Has a hint of bitterness with a medium bodied feel.

Bottle shared. Hazy amber with big beige head. Light roasted malts with a bit of a cocoa touch, grass after some rain, orange peel, caramel, dried apricot, kumquat. Medium sweet and bitter. Bit over medium bodied with great creamy carbonation. Nice!

On tap at SLL tasting and 500ml bottle. Pours a crystal clear dark amber with an light tan head and sticky lacing. Smell is dark dried fruit, citrus, pine and cocoa with biscuit malt aromas. Taste is raisin, citrus fruit, pine resin and dark chocolate with biscuit malt flavors. Feel is medium in body with a smooth clean finish.

500 ml bottle from notes. Pours a clear, deep amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel malts, lightly toasted, grapefruit citrus, resin, some earthy notes, herbal, solid hoppy amber.

Smells of sweet Orange and lemon peel with sweet malts to end the scent with. Super dark purple color with two finger off white head. Nice deep flavor starting out with sweet malts and a bit of cherry with a touch of raisin and pine resin. Fullish body with light tasty carbonation. All in all nice well rounded brew that all Maine beer companies should be putting out. Nice brew keep up the great work.

Bottle dates 3/15/16. Pours cloudy Amber color with dense lasting one finger head. Soapy lacing. Good bitter flavor. Not much citrus or anything very aromatic about it. Not my favorite style but a good drinkable beer for it nonetheless.

Tap in a snifter glass for ECBT at The Farmhouse with commonshawn, rosskyle, and samadouche. Sports a deeper amber hue with an off white head. Nose is cereal and malt with a hop pine undertone. Brings to mind a red IPA initially but once you taste it, you realize its definitely an amber ale. Caramel and toasted nutty characteristics. Little syrupy. Malty cereal finish with some mild bitterness that consumes the aftertaste. I would jump at the chance to date Zoe again.

Served on tap at Maine Beer. Red Amber color with white head. Mild sweet malt aroma. Copper malt flavor. Smooth medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at Luckys, 4/8/16.A glassy, ruddy amber body has a strong blonde tint and a moderate sized, light beige head atop with moderate to strong retention.Fruity hops give off strawberry, raspberry and very light pineapple-like notes, as the specialty malts mix in to add soft caramel, brown bread and such. Pretty well-balanced between the two, though tending hoppier unsurprisingly, with pine and red grapefruit picking up as the beer warms, especially on the finish. Fresh yeast and no alcohol or flaws.In the mouth its bitter, not intensely so, but what Ive come to expect from MBC. The fruitiness of the hops here, along with a fair amount of honey-caramel sweetness from the malt is enough to entertain and balance, at least initially. As the pint goes on, breadiness and light sourdough from the specialty malt, as well as pine/resin definitely build up on the palate. Probably a bit too much for me to ever drink more than one, but well-made no doubt. Could use a little less bready-sourdough character (none would be perfect). Tightly carbonated though and clean.

Pint at Giant Eagle in Upper Arlington: copper-amber pour, dirty white head. aroma of resin, pine, nutty. tastes are earthy, herbal, toffee, grain, pine, citrus. even bitter finish. tingly carbonation. I dont typically like ambers, but this is quality.

July 22, 2015. On tap at the brewery. 
Clear deep amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is malty and hoppy with toffee, crisp biscuit, notes of red berries, citrus, pine, resin and peach. Taste is light to medium sweet with toffee, fruits and berries, a whiff of roasted malts, piney, light dry bitter finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation.

On tap poured into a teku glass..amber with a fluffy
white head..aroma of caramel,pine,resin,grapefruit..
Tastes like it smells..medium body..good stuff.

Lunivers des bières rousses et ambrées au Québec est loin dêtre exceptionnel. Ça fait du bien dessayer une ambrée fort populaire provenant des voisins du Sud. Au nez, cette rousse au gros collet de mousse sent un mélange très caramélisé et floral, cest fort prometteur. Les arômes sont assez fidèles au goût, oèu cest très caramel au départ, laissant place èa une finale sucrée et amère. On sent un peu lalcool pour une 7,2%, juste assez pour trouver un certain équilibre entre le caramel, le houblon floral et laspect liquoreux de lalcool. Il en résulte une bière avec beaucoup de caractère.

Poured from 16.9 ounce bottle from Delhi Liquor, tasted on April 15, 2016. Dark brown/amber hue, nice bittersweet aroma with interesting mustiness, good complex bittersweet flavor with finish thats a bit off, but that could be because my bottle was a little old. Still, a really good beer.
Hoppy, but not too bitter. Great taste! Pretty color. One one of my favorites!
16.9 oz bottle. Deep Amber with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of fresh figs, pine, grapefruit, booze. Taste is of pine, grapefruit, burnt caramel, resin, and grass.

Outstanding Ale! Very Hop Forward but the malts do balance it out - caramel and some chocolate do come through to the taste! Bottling date on the beer 3/15/16 Thank You! Lately I noticed that some bottles do not have Bottling dates and with hoppy beers that cannot happen! Maine Beer company beers are very special beers and I am ecstatic that I can get them at my local supermarket! 16 oz. bottle. Pours a deep amber color with a reddish hue. 1/2" light tan head that settles to a film leaving some lacing. Pleasant aroma of fruit, citrus and malt. Medium body, great balance of malt and hops. Just a touch of roastedness and fruit at the finish. Very good!

This beer pours a reddish-amber color with a medium foamy white head that recedes gradually to an outer ring. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, floral hops and pine. Medium body with flavors of grainy malt, piney hops and citrus. The finish is malty up front with a lingering resiny hops aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Bottle from the Greenville beer exchange. Deep mahogany pour with a small off white head. Aroma was deep dark fruit, piney hops, caramel. Flavors were in the same vein with more caramel, resinous hops, fruit cake, mild yet lingering bittersweet finish. Medium plus mouthfeel with perfect carbonation. Very nicely done hoppy amber.
Tap at Maine Beer Company, Freeport. Originally rated 20160221. Colour is cloudy copper with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Caramel, some chocolate, some fruits, hops and malts.

BOD 1/5/16. Pours dark amber which turns a brilliant clear dark ruby under intense light. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

Outstanding, but a bit light, complex nose of citrus, pith, hints of dark fruit (fig, raisin), pine and a touch of caramel over a malt base with strong dark toasted notes.

Almost heavy medium body that is quite smooth and has a nice touch of creaminess to it. Superb carbonation with a fair burst of effervescence in the middle and a finely bubbled prickly finish.

The flavor profile is outstanding. Flavor arrives in a blended fashion that has minimal separation. It has the flavors of the nose, with dark toasted grainy malt being the most evident part of the base. Dark fruit (prune) and citric pith are the main components with a touch of pine arriving in the very mildly bittered middle. Balance is achieved with little perceived sweetness and has a very subtle caramel note. The finish is a slow fade of prune and pith.
From BNC. Fresh hops, almost a cherry flavor? If you are a hop head youll love it, but this was just too much hops. Serving: Bottle
Deep red color on pour. Love the nutty malty roast, bit of biscuit flavor. The hops have a bit of honey and mango and pineapple to it. Really balanced and hope to have one again. Love it!

500 ml bottle, stamp on label says bottled on 121515. Served in a snifter, the beer pours a dark reddish/amber color with about an inch and a half light tan head. Head retention is good, and theres a lot of lacing. Aroma is nice, the brew smells like toasted malt, dark fruit (raisins), pine hops, citrusy hops and some bready malt. For the most part I think the taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also some chocolate and woody earthiness noticeable. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its smooth, creamy, easy to drink and has a good amount of carbonation. I think this is a pretty good amber ale, Id buy this again in the future. $6.99 a bottle.

A beer buddy shared this, and I didnt check the bottle for a date, but it seems old. High carbonation. Light hops and strong malt aroma. Taste is roasted grain, phenolic / citrus hops, very dry with very little sweetness. Palate feels very lightweight - like something is missing. Not terrible, but not good either.

Bottled 12/15/2015 and enjoyed 1/3/2016 in a snifter.

Look - Dark red, almost brown. Darker tan head than others. Medium bubbles settle to a ring. Lacing. 

Smell - Bread. Caramel. Malt. Pine. Peach. Citrus. 

Taste - Pine. Caramel malt. Light citrus. 

Feel - Bitter rips tongue. Light alcohol. Carbonation is high. 

Overall - This is a style than many do well. This isnt the best or the worst. Light citrus/peach aroma is unique in something I havent had before.

Distro just hit Ohio. Obviously no Lunch or anything, but still some awesome offerings. Perfect amber pour with two finger off-white head. Nose of initial sweet toasted malt, floral and juicy lemony hops. Tate of gently toasted, rounded malt on the bottom end....flowery hoppiness, rindy linger. Very clean for an amber. Cleanliness seems to be a theme with this brewery. I can get with that.

Thanks to Thomas for sharing this. i am drinking it in the dark at Darkness day. Fairly heavy hop aroma and flavor, on the line between an amber ale or a red ipa. Hops are strong, well carbonated, good looking beer to the extent i can see it, it does have a nice lacing head. One of the best amber ales I have had the chance to try.

Beautiful beer. One of those beers I wish I would have bought more of. Well balanced ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear auburn with a full inch of light brown head that leaves substantial lacing. Hoppy aroma of tropical fruit, peach, fresh grass, and clover. Malts and floral scents come through as it warms. Juicy fruit taste, bitter grapefruit rind, some herbals, lemongrass, and an earthy maltiness. Nice stinging bitter finish. Well crafted, very enjoyable.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2015 Fruity, colorful hops define the aromatics: light apricot and green mango, pineapple jam, and powdery floral notes are put together by a touch of toffee and honey wheat bread in the background. Spicy pepper and mild pine add a slight kick to it. The mouthfeel is firm, with a medium-to-light body and adequate carbonation. The taste is hoppy bitter, with implied malty sweetness. Peppery, piney flavors give way to mango peel and grapefruit as the beer goes down, for a green, dry, slightly earthy aftertaste. Excellent as a beer on the whole, intricately hopped and very engaging -- if not whats on my mind when I think amber ale.

Keg pour at NH Brewfest. Appearance is amber reddish, no sparkle, little head with decent lacing. Aroma is dominant hops--pine, grass with a bit of hay, some corn. Taste is dominant bitter--resin, pine. Palate is light-to-medium with average to lively carbonation and bitter finish. Overall, fans of pale ale on the bitter side will enjoy this. Decent complexity but too far to the bitter side for me.
Pours a brownish amber color with a puffy off white head. Notes of toasted grains, orange citrus, brown sugar, and fresh air.

Where: Old Line Fine Wine Spirits & Bistro. 
How: 500 ml bottle.
Appearance: Dark copper with a one finger tan head. 
Aroma: Pine and bready malts, coffee and citrus. 
Taste: Pine, bready malts, citrus (mainly grapefruit), light tropical fruits. 
Palate: Medium body and creamy. 
Overall: Pretty fantastic.
Bottle in Chevy Chase, MD. Nice amber body with medium, toasty head. Nose is quite hoppy, with caramel and toffee too. Taste of hops and pine and honey. Nice and prickly texture. Enjoyable.

Tap. Murky reddish brown, light khaki head. Toffee, toast, citrus hoppiness, and slight toasted bread in the aroma. Flavor is similar, slight dark fruit sweetness, some earthy hops, citrus, and toasted toffee. Lighter to medium slick body.
Nicely done. Pours reddish orange with an off white head. Aroma is earthy hop aroma with caramel notes. Finishes earthy with a light hop bite.
Au nez on sent le houblon et un peu de poivre. Ces saveurs reveinnent en bouche avec une touche de torréfaction suivie dune amertume sèche
Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a mostly lasting foamy white head. Aroma of pine, grassy, caramel, nuts. Taste is of more resinous pine, red fruits, nuts. Medium carbonation, oily mouthfeel.
On tap at Hopleaf. Pours near black with a nice tan head and a zesty red aroma. There is a dry raspy red malt flavor, the epitome of amber ale. Lovely.

Pour dark copper with a one finger tan head with nice lacing. Aroma is of pine/spruce, toasted bready malts, caramel, toffee, iced tea notes, light grapefruit citrus, light dankness, and light tropical fruits. Taste is spruce and pine, toasted bready malts, caramel, sweet malts, toffee, black tea, citrus (mainly grapefruit), light tropical fruits, light herbal notes, and some light coffee in the finish. Has a medium body with a creamy, soft mouthfeel and a moderately bitter, semi dry, long, lingering finish. Overall, a fantastic, hoppy amber ale that may be my new favorite for the style.
Floral/citrus hops. Pours super dark copper with a quick fading wide head. Bitter flavor. Dry. Some hop flavor towards the end. Bitter easily dominant.

Dark amber pour with minimal head. Hoppy aroma. Very smooth and drinkable. It wasnt too hoppy and was in fact very balanced. Malty with caramel notes with only a touch of alcohol despite the alcohol percentage. An amazing beer.

Type: 500ml (16.9-oz.) bottle 
Glass: Firestone pint glass 
From: Eddys Beverage Inc. in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. 
Price: $6.99 
Purchased: July 14, 2015
Consumed: July 18, 2015
Misc.: Born on April 28, 2015

Poured a caramel, reddish amber, semi-clear color with a whopping seven fingers of khaki tan, frothy head. A few light bubble streams coming up from the bottom of the glass. Good amount of thick, layered foamy lacing on the sides of the glass. Great retention on the top. (Sight - 3.88)

Smelled a pleasant whiff of hops and malts. Getting wet Cascade, rye, sugary iced tea powder, sticky toffee, caramel, dry roasty notes, chocolate covered orange candy, dark fruits, faint cooked vegetables and some Citra zest. (Smell - 4.00)

Taste follows the nose nicely. Got the nice mix of hops and malts again. Wet Cascade, earthy rye, powdery iced tea mix, toffee, dark fruits, roasted nuts, caramel, toasty biscuit and still that chocolate covered orange candy (one of the Sees Candy). Really good for the style. (Taste - 4.25)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long finish. (Feel - 4.25)

I really liked this beer. This was all over the place for me, especially the taste and feel. Really good for the style. Wouldnt be as high if it was an IPA (imperial IPA). (Overall - 4.13)

4.16 93 A-

Pours cloudy light brown with a finger of light tan head. Aroma of citrus, light grapefruit and caramel, light nuts and roasty notes. Taste is balanced mellow hoppy bitter with caramel sweet backbone. Light, smooth body with average carbonation.

Aroma of spice, floral, very flowery with a spruce note, not very citrusy hops but more herbal and apricot pear like. Taste gives a earthy malt body with almost rye notes, not traditional caramel sweetness, this beer is quite dry, reminds me a bit of a Sahti, but with a refreshing hop twist.

Bottle at the Breens Hampton house. Pours murky dark Amber, frothy off white head that persists. Tons of pine and earth malt grain notes. Hoppy dark brown ale characteristics and a hit chewy. Tasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml bottle shared by Bvery...thanks man! Dark cloudy amber pour. Hop forward aroma. Taste follows with bitterness lasting. Liking the wheelbarrow better but this is still awesome.
The shining star of the non-lottery beers at World of Beer Fest. A very drinkable beer, this one goes down smooth. Toffee and caramel flavor with a mildly bitter finish. Outstanding.

On tap at Church Key, DC. More or less clear in the glass, amber in color, topped by a small, dense, light beige head. The aroma its on the malty, almost meaty side at first, followed by bread, caramel notes, grapefruit and some pond cones. Its full bodied and smooth, with a nice carbonation level. Where the malts dominated the aroma, the hops run the show in the flavor. Grapefruit and pine cones, with bready malts in the back. Lasting finish. Quite nice this one, how an amber ale should be. 150620

Brown bottle, 1 pint 0.9 ounces, beat before 081714, purchased at DeCiccos, trip to Bacon and beer classic (New York), savoured on June 16 2015; eye: dark brown, opaque, nice beige head that turns into a thin sheet, average lacing; nose: hops, malt, slight fruity, light citrusy, slight grapefruit; mouth: hops, malt, light grapefruit, bittering hops, finale in bittering hops with good presence of malt, medium-full body, average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 0,9 onces, 7,2 %, meilleure avant 081714, achetée chez DeCicos, voyage au Bacon and beer classic (New York), savourée le 16 juin 2015; il : brun foncé, opaque, bonne mousse beige qui se transforme en une minuscule couche, dentelle moyenne; nez : houblon, malt, très léger fruité, léger citrique, très léger pamplemousse; bouche : houblon, malt, léger pamplemousse, houblon amérisant, finale en houblon amérisant avec présence de malt, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amère, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : bien

first provided by Dj Marky, and had a few times since then, this stuff never seems fresh? .. . orange .. medium foam .. . fake sandwich .. . mouth is decent, finish is always just in time .. unless i get this on tap one day, i don;t see the score improving .. . . Well, looks like Helen is gonna get a beatin tonight!

Pours hazy brown with thick and frothy tan head. Nice brown lacing. Nose is caramel, cafe latte, nuts. Aromas are coffee, pepper, licorice, some alcohol. Oily texture, average carbonation. Long alcoholic and spicy finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Aroma of whole wheat bready grains, some c-hops. Grainy toasty taste, not much caramel, c-hops, and a very dry bitter finish. Tastes more "brown" than "amber" to me, if you know what I mean. Looks more brown too.

500 ml bottle purchased at 7-11, Kittery. Jason is still doing a great job as the manager of this store! Selection is always up-to-date and spot on. Color is copper with lasting head. Aro,a is toasted grain, caramel and mild grapefruit. 
The base is that of a standard Amber ale with toffee, grain and caramel. The hops are a mix of grapefruit and moderate pine. The bitterness shows me dry pine with a gritty texture. Kind of dirty. Highly drinkable but nowhere near my favorite from this brewery.

Bottle. Moderate roasted grain, herbs and pine for the hops, light leather for the yeast, with wood and pepper in the background. Head is average size, frothy/creamy light beige with excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear, but murky on the last pour, brown with a red tint. Flavor starts faintly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, slick with a lively carbonation and finishes dry. Nice to have an Amber Ale with a touch of flavor and complexity.

First time having a beer from MBC, and I have to say I like their attitude (at least what I can gather from the label.) I also like there beer, Pours the advertised amber, leaning toward the brown scale, with some cloud. Big hop nose of resin, and a little pine. Very smooth taste, heavy on the hops for an "ale" but with a good balance of resins, mild bitterness, a little perfume with a mildly sweet caramel malt backbone. Mild bitterness on the after. Very nice, a well balanced beer. And now its gone. Sigh.

Aroma: spruce, caramel, citrus, 
Appearance: hazy amber with full tan head
Taste: light sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long bitter finish, 

Very good

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep amber copper color with a tan head. Aroma is a wonderful mix of amber malts, and a great hop presence, fruity, piney, spicy. Flavor has a great balance of malt backbone with a decent hop presence. A very nice beer. Although I expect nothing less from Maine.

Aroma is amazingly piney hops. Pours dark brown with a great head. Flavor is tart and sweet, fruity and balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bière dont la première chose qui frappe est son look denfer! De couleur ambrée presque brune, cette dernière affiche une magnifique et fier collet monté et mousseux à souhait. En de dissipant, les parois du verre se joliement décorées de dentelles soyeuses et complexes. En faisant tournoyer le liquide dans le verre, celui-ci semble plutôt charpenté sous la mousse - chronique dun corps attendu. Mon nez est violemment attaqué par un houblon floral et résineux à souhait! Ça sent le sapin à plein nez ainsi quun houblon dune grande fraîcheur. Le liquide na pas encore traversé mes lèvres quil me désaltère déjà! En bouche lensemble est très homogène quoiquun côté très sec à cette bière coupe court dans les saveurs et la bière se retire rapidement pour laisser derrière elle une traînée plutôt âcre et une sensation légèrement râpeuse sur ma langue. Les céréales sont délicates et ajoutent un côté noisette des plus agréables. Très bonne bière.
Bottle. Dark cooper with big head. Smells peachy and twizzlery and grainy with a whiff of pine. caramel comes out in the flavor. I may have waited too long to drink this.

Pours cloudy dark amber with a thick, foamy khaki colored head. Aroma is citrus, floral, spicy pepper & pine. Big hop forward grapefruit start followed by biscut malt and mineral notes. Finishes dry citrus and big pine hop bitterness.

Labeled 1/28/15, so I?m drinking it about 45 days post bottling. Giant foamy brownish white head. Dissipates really slowly. Lemon huge on the nose, refreshing. Hazelnut brown appearance with some red tones. Some wonderful hop note on the front with the body of a brown ale. This is interesting. In fact, I love this.

Really confused about the fresh notes everyone else is mentioning. This bottle is stamped one month ago, and is devoid of fresh hop notes. Even tastes a little phenolic, like it was fermented too hot. Some pine resin in the background, but otherwise medicinal over too much malt. Really disappointed by this one.

Very good for an amber. Large white head that dissipates slowly. Smell is very hop foreward for the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle into an English pint. Pours a gorgeous opaque amber, with lasting off-white head and plenty of lacing. Nose is big-time citrusy hops with grapefruit predominant. Similar citrus flavour, but a bit lighter on the palate. Good hoppy, bitter bite to it. As usual, a solid Maine Beer Co. brew! Probably better sampled mid-summer.

Gorgeous dark amber color. Huge notes of pine, citrus and tropical fruit. It just explodes out of the bottle as soon as you open the top. It smells like some of the best IPAs out there. Taste is like biting into a fresh grapefruit. Really big grapefruit and tropical fruit. The "hoppy, hoppy" part is definitely there. For an "amber ale" it tastes like some of the best IPAs out there. Better than a lot of them as well. This is the first Maine Brewing beer I have had and I highly recommend it. Absolutely delicious. Cheers!

Poured out of a 22 oz bottle. A deep Amber color, pleasant aroma of light hops. First sip had plenty of malt, the rest of the glass the hops showed
Up. They were not overpowering like many hyper hopped beers. A great, clean Amber. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A good rich ipa. Not overpowering bitter. Not a lot else to me outside of the usual ipa flavor though
It has a strong bitter kick immediately and then dies off. The hops are potent with a sharp bitter taste. You could easily mistake this for an IPA.
Bottle from Philly craft. Interesting brew with a bit going on. Notes of Pine needles, caramel malts, lemon, grapefruit and citrus. Finishes piney and sweet, with a dry bitterness. Odd , but good.
Dark amber foamy poor. Hoppy smell of roasted malty delight and medium bodied. Very nice dry finish. Give Zoe a swig. Cheers
Bottled 12/16/14. Maine beer company does it right. Beautiful amber ale. Love the story behind it.

On tap at Maine Beer Co. Pour was an amber/copper color with an eggshell colored head that lasts for a while...only settling to a cap before I finished. Nice aromas of dank pine, grapefruit rind and a sweet cereal base. Taste was nice bitter hops upfront..plenty of earth and pine...balanced by a nice grapefruit/orange peel middle ground before some sweet roasted malted goodness balance out a juicy, lingering hop finish. Solid!!

Translucent and ruby red in color. A foamy off white head that is one finger in depth, disspates farily quickly. Grapefruit forward in the aroma with a malty backbone. A lot of carbonation in this beer. Definite grapefruit in the taste along with grassy and herbal notes. Nice caramel undertones with a lingering bitterness.
Clear amber pour with light tan head. Aroma is malty and nutty. Taste follows nose. Roast nut and a hint of copper. Very nice.

Flight at brewery. Way more hoppy than I would expect for an amber. Should like it more than I do as the style is usually overly sweet and malty for my palate. Hops come through first and smooth maltiness comes through mid-palate. Finishes dry. Pours a copper color with a nice tan head. Looks more like a brown. Dankness of Columbus hops is muted. Somewhat astrigent. and resiny. Will give it another go. Take one for the team.

Pours a reddish brown with plenty of white head which diminishes to a light lacy coating. Smells of lemongrass with a hint of wheat. Taste is crisp and refreshing with citrus hints. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beautiful looking amber. Perfect balance between hops and malt with a lovely mouthfeel. Not many better ambers around!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep burgundy red bordering on brown, with an immensely frothy brown head that reminds me of the layer of foam you would find on an indulgent milkshake. Aroma is resinous hops and slight oily nut aroma. Taste is caramel, hazelnuts and bitter finish with some grapefruit thrown in somewhere. Full bodied. One of the best ambers I have had, malty sweet and hop bitter.
A very nice malt arome with some sweetness. A very balanced amber with plenty of hops, what a great amber!

500, capped. Pours a murky medium amber with a loose and sudsy stacked tan head. Big sweet light caramel and bright grapefruit nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Great balance of malt and hops in a perfectly leveled body weight. Great refreshing and complex beer showing flavors very well.

Bottle at home, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear dark blond beer, huge stable off white head.
NOSE: fruity, hoppy, sweet.

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 7/22/14 and cost $6 ($0.36 per bottle).

Appearance: Beautiful mahogany/maroon shade. Fairly clear body. Pours to a huge, off-white, frothy head which laces and retains wonderfully.

Smell: Strong hoppy sensation of flowers and a hint of berry or other fruity scents.

Taste: I always say Im not a fan of amber ales, but there are certain examples of the style that really impress me and Maine Beer Zoe is a great example of what I mean. As is typical of the brewery, the hops are prominent here, though the malt base is a bit more vital to the palette of this beer than of their IPAs. Id prefer it to be more balanced, but whats here is delectable indeed.

Assertive bitterness from beginning to end, with a taste of flowers, pine, and a hint of tea or herbal sensation (due to the Simcoe, Columbus and Centennial hops, respectively). The brewerys website list seven different malts, though the actual palette is not quite as complex as youd think. Marris Otter gives is a touch of English character, with slight cherry flavor. Theres a light confectionery sweetness hiding in the background thats noticeable if you look for it. Otherwise, the hops carry the load and impart tasty bitterness and give it a slightly astringent, resin-like taste on the back end. Whats here is enjoyable to be sure, though a more truly balanced brew would be amazing Ill bet.

Drinkability: Zoe would seem to be a hefty beer at 7.2% ABV, however, it drinks like something smaller and more mainstream. The mouthfeel itself is soft, smooth and creamy  not quite as crisp as most ambers. The hops do linger and leave a minor dry bitterness on the tongue, but its easily tolerable. I could see this being quite versatile when it comes to food pairings.

A: Pours a very dark yet cloudy copper color. Theres about one fingers worth of off-white colored head, and its beautifully textured. It retains itself acceptably, as well.

Its easy to walk by beers by the Maine Beer Company without noticing them; their inconspicuous labels blend them in to the background of the beer store. That said, their beers are almost universally praises, almost all of them sporting 95+ scores on Ratebeer. I decided to grab one at the beer store to celebrate the weekend and see whether or not the scores are justified.

Appearance (5/5)
Zoe is an attractive beer in the glass, thats for sure. It pours a deep amber color with a touch of ruby, and the thick khaki head is reminiscent of the head on a root beer float. A big thumbs up right from the start.

Aroma (9/10)
This doesnt really smell like an amber ale. When I pick up an amber, I usually expect primarily malt notes with maybe a trace of hop presence. This, on the other hand, has that malt body and backbone, but it is balanced with an intense pine and resin hop character that stands out prominently.

Taste (15/20)
Based on the appearance and the aroma, I was ready to be absolutely floored by Zoe. Up front, there is a sticky resin and pine hop character that is to be expected based on the aroma. This makes way to a predominantly malty middle with a noticeable nut flavor. It finishes off with a bitter, smoky aftertaste that lingers, but not entirely in a good way. This is, without a doubt, a bold amber/IPA hybrid, and the beginning of the flavor profile supports the rave reviews, but the smoke and nut in the finish doesnt work well for be with the resin notes. Its good, but not amazing.

Drinkability (3/5)
I was conflicted between thinking this was a beer I could drink many of and one that I had to take my time with. Based on the beginning of the palate, the aroma, and the appearance, Id give this a 5, but the finish drops it down for me.

Intangibles (6/10)
I can see why people speak highly of Maine Beer Company, and this beer has made me want to try more of their beers, but there was something about this that doesnt blow me away. That and there is the fact that a single bottle of the stuff is $7.50.

Overall (38/50)

Big thanks to my NorEaster buddy Eli for this bottle.  Enjoyed late at night alone with the super-good Journey soundtrack.

  A.  Looks like an Oud Bruin.  Deep russet, fall colors.  A medium, uneven burgundy-tinged head lingers.  Very little lace, spotty.  Quite clear. The head, incidentally, lasts for ever.  

  S.  In a word: grand.  Terrific balance here, malty and "red" for sure, but lots of caramel malt.  The comparisons to Nugget Nectar are inevitable.  The hops are both fruity and herbal in measure.  There is a soft, malt driven, polished sweetness and a perfume note (sandalwood?) that brings to mind the fine Hitachino brews out of the East.  Some beers try to shoehorn in a lot of ingredients and hope for this best, Zoe, by contrast, is simple, direct, and mojo filled.

  T.  Simply the finest Amber ale Ive had to date.  Zoe is a masterful, magic blend of semi-sweet malt sugar and balancing bitter, nuanced hop.  There is a tremendous depth to this beer, but like many such beers, its very hard to nail down.  Harmonious only begins to describe it.  The hop flavor - earthy, damp, bitter, dry, green - blends so well into the malt - sweet, fruity, complex, gently toasted, red - that they become one.  There are no steps or stages.  The finish is gently sweet and fades out, leaving a dry, bitter-green finish that is long and moreish. This is amazingly well brewed beer.  

  M / P.  Full, rounded carbonation exudes confidence.  Zoe is absolutely sessionable, despite the rather high 7.2% alcohol, which is nowhere to be found.

  Zoe is simply superb beer, a unique take on an little brewed style (in this case, Imperial Amber) and is such a self=assured, lush and harmonious beer that it deserves great praise.  This is what American craft brewing is all about.  I tip my hat to Maine brewing company.  Everyone should enjoy Zoe.

Bouteille de 500 ml. Arômes très intéressants de houblon résineux et fruité et de malt rappelant les fruits rouges et le caramel foncé. Robe rubis plutôt foncée, effervescence dintensité moyenne et belle mousse qui tient bien. En bouche, le houblon aromatique est très frais, présentant une personnalité fruitée et résineuse. Le malt contribue une présence de caramel brûlé et de fruits rouges, mais demeure adéquatement pas trop sucré. Finale présentant une amertume dintensité moyenne. Cette bière présente plusieurs points en commun avec une Arrogant Bastard et est également excellente.

Rojo oscuro que a contraluz se ve de un rojo bien intenso. Buena espuma y buen aroma alupulos citricos. En boca entra suave pero luego se siente un cuerpo de mediana inensidad, el alcohol ni se siente...peligrosa! Destaca por su amargor citrico, bien rica. Como para conocedores y para los iniciados que gustan de una buena cerveza amarga. Me gusto mucho, ideal para el verano ya que es refrescante, sin dejar de ser una cerveza interesante. Bien equilibrada. Un 10 para este verano!

Date: September 16, 2011
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: cloudy amber, fine beige head, bits of lace
Aroma: sweet bready aroma, lots of hops, touch of citrus
Flavor: big hop flavor, backing bready sweetness, balancing earthy bitterness, long bitter finish
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4

Perfect.  If I could drink a beer everyday then this would be it.  Slightly hazy copper pour with a 1 inch frothy head.  Caramel malt and grassy hops come right through.   Taste is medium to heavy bitter with a long let off.  Thanks a million mcox90!

Draft.  Pours brown with creamy tan head.  Nose is caramel malt, figgy fruit, hops.  Tastes vienna malty, figgy and somewhat vinous fruity, with a pronounced citric hop bill and mild cacao hints.  Complex and very enjoyable.

From a bottle. Pours dark amber brown with cream head. Thick aroma, resinous hops, little chocolate in the background, some dark fruit. Taste is a harmony of hops, caramel, toffee, raisins and chocolate. Slightly bitter finish. Very bloody nice
Pours a clear and dark brown with a large offwhite head. The aroma is hops with citrus and grapefruit. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a good beer.

Bottle shared my Mike - Thanks!  Clear ruby/brown body, off white head.  Nose is a bit piney, fruity & caramel, nutty malt, a little cocoa.  Flavor is dusty malt, roast pine, light burnt character.  Malt character has a bit in common with pre-FX Matt takeover Flying Bison beers.

Deep amber pour thin off white head little soapy with light striped lacing ...... aroma is of chewy caramel malts and citrusy/floral/piney hops and slight biscuit ....... taste is chewy caramel malts, citrusy floral and piney hops, biscuity and a light bitter hop bite .... mouthfeel is oily and medium .... the caramel malt and oily dry hop floral hop lingers in the finish .... a very sessionable brew abv is hidden well .... these guys are winners
bottle, darker amber pour, toffee, pine, spruce in the pretty substantial aroma. big maltiness paired with a hefty piney bitterness. One of the best ambers ive had.

Shared by InspectorBob during the 11 NJBA gathering. Poured a brown/amber body with a full foamy head. Aroma was lousy with notes of grains and vegetables. The body was medium to fuller with average to stronger carbonation and a lingering finish. The flavor was much better then the aroma with lots of hoppy citrus, chocolate and toast. A better aroma would do worlds for this beer.
Draft at CAH. Pours a dark mahoganey color with nice head and decent lacing.   Nose is brown malt, citrus. Finish with slight brown sugar with bitter hops quickly.

Draught at Whole Foods Devon:  Aroma of fruit, hops, malt, pine, and a slight citrus.  Poured copper/brown/deep amber in color with a small, tan/brown rocky, creamy, loose head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, hops, pine, slight dark caramel, and some resin.  Medium body.  Slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium bitter, lightly sweet, malt, hop, slight dark caramel, pine, resin, slight diacetyl finish is slightly dry.

Clear copper amber in the glass.  Sweet grape aroma.  Some new carpet, grass clippings and weed as well.  Clean citrusy pine flavor with a toasty malt backbone to support it.  Overall, its simply awesome...  Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing his bottle!

Pours dark brown with a very thick tan head...great lacing and retention!  Aroma is roasty with a hint of chocolate and lots of spicy hoppiness.  Flavor has burnt toffee and chocolate up front with lots of hoppiness to back it up...tastes like a black ipa.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with a roasty, hoppy finish...awesome beer!

16 oz bottle poured into HFB stemware. Dark brown with red hues. Light tan head with sticky lacing. Nose is light citrus hops, and some sweet candied orange. Taste is fresh leafy hops, lots of resin, caramel, grapefruit and lemon, a bit of orange. Very well balanced. Another solid offering from Maine.

500ml bottle:  Pours a dark cloudy orange with a large rocky white head, aroma has oranges, lemons and grass, starts and ends bitter with a long spicy hop ending, medium bodied with playful carbonation.  Im not sure that I would call this an amber ale, but it is a tasty treat.

Cold, 16.9oz bottle:  Pours a cloudy medium amber color with a huge, fluffy ivory head that leaves lacing. Aroma is of malt, fruit and wood, with notes of pine.  Taste is of lightly roasted malts and resin, with some fruit and pine.  Medium bodied with fizzy carbonation.  Ending is distinctly minty.
Draft. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweet and fruity hoppy aroma with a light toffee sweetness. The flavor has juicy sweet malts, sweet citric hops, and floral notes. Really good.

500mL Bottle, purchased at Brookline Liquors - Brookline, MA. How are these beer so perfect? God, this nose is great. Its the perfect arrangement of American aroma and flavor hops. Resin, tropical, and mint. Flavors are so sharp, neat, and well-defined, perfectly clean and structured. Dry and fresh, with an impeccable balance of malt sugar and hop bitterness. A magically wonderful Amber Ale.

#1400, and it was a good one!  The label looks like it was printed out on somebodys home computer.  The aroma grabbed my attention - sweet, floral hops, bread, a little coffee.  Dark pour with a thick, foamy head.  Zoe tastes roasty, dry, and astringent with plenty of mocha-espresso flavor.  Now (finally) here is an amber I really like (even if it is a touch dry for me).  Mmm...veravera good.

Really loving this beer at the moment. Such an amazing hop profile, Wonderful citrus hop aroma, balanced flavours , huge hop on the palette, perfectly balanced. I dont know of a better tasting amber beer actually Id go as far to say this is currently one of my favourites all round and I cant wait for more beers from Maine Beer
copper with a lasting off-white head. Fruity hops, some grapefruit and pine. Dry fruity flavour with grapefruit, pine and peach, a touch of bread crust and a bitter finish

Bottle from Good beer NYC.
Pours dark amber with a big yellowish head.
Hoppy aroma, citrusy taste with cookies.

Bottle shared thanks to InspectorBob. Pours out a very attractive amber color (go figure) with a decent white head. Aroma is of some light caramel, some fruity citrus hops and light toffee. Taste is much the same with a good balance of hops and sweetness with light bready notes in there. Nice easy drinking beer that drinks more like a 5% or so.

5-11-11 Bouteille 500ml:Belle coueleur ambrée rougeâtre, trouble, avec une légère effervescence. Mousse très abondante au départ, mais disparait asser rapidement laissant un beau petit collet beige. Puissants arômes de houblon, de sapins, dépinettes avec des notes de noix grillées. Moyenne amertume en bouche, mais plus puissante en arrière goût. Bon backbone de malt et présence de saveurs de noix. Corps léger-moyen avec une texture plutôt mince, une faible carbonisation et une finale asser astringente.
